full_history.content: Show me Section 101.1 of the Virginia Building Code.

As a code expert specializing in the Virginia Building Code, I can clarify Section 101.1 for you. This section establishes the short title for the relevant part of the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code (USBC). Understanding this foundational element is crucial for navigating the code effectively.

Here's a detailed breakdown based on the research:

* **Core Definition of 101.1:** Section 101.1 defines the short title for different parts of the USBC. For the building construction portion (Part I), the short title is “Virginia Construction Code” or “VCC.”  For existing buildings (Part II), it's the “Virginia Existing Building Code” or “VEBC.”  “USBC” generally refers to the VCC unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. This distinction is crucial for understanding which part of the code applies to your project.

* **Contextual Usage of "USBC":**  While "USBC" typically stands for the VCC (new construction), it can sometimes refer to the entire Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code or a different part. Pay close attention to the specific language used in each section to avoid confusion. The research results confirm this nuanced usage.

* **Importance for Citation and Reference:**  Knowing the correct short title is essential for properly citing the code and ensuring clear communication in legal and professional settings. Using the official abbreviations (VCC, VEBC, USBC) adds clarity and professionalism to your documentation.

* **Variations Across Code Editions:** While the core concept of 101.1 remains consistent, the specific edition of the Virginia Construction Code (e.g., 2015, 2018, 2021) will determine the exact wording and referenced International Building Code (IBC) version.  Always double-check you're using the correct edition for your project.  Our research has uncovered instances of different years and their corresponding IBC versions, highlighting this importance.

To proceed, confirm the specific edition of the Virginia Construction Code you're working with. This will ensure you are referencing the correct provisions throughout your project. If you're dealing with existing buildings, remember to consult the VEBC and its associated sections. This proactive approach will save you time and ensure code compliance from the start.
